section_title: Meniscal Allograft Transplantation of the Knee (Evidence: pg no: 17, L726)
names: Meniscal allograft transplantation (Evidence: pg no: 17, L728)
Meniscal allograft transplantation of the knee (Evidence: pg no: 17, L786)
description: Surgical procedure used to restore normal meniscal function by replacing damaged or absent meniscus with donor cadaver allograft cartilage (Evidence: pg no: 17, L728-L730)
scope: Treatment for patients with pain or disability attributed to insufficient cushioning and lubrication of joint (Evidence: pg no: 17, L730-L733)

documentation: Operative report of prior arthroscopic procedure and/or MRI of knee performed within past 12 months (Evidence: pg no: 17, L742-L743)
Conservative management including physical therapy AND at least ONE complementary conservative treatment strategy (Evidence: pg no: 17, L747-L767)
Age 55 or younger and skeletally mature (Evidence: pg no: 18, L790)
Knee pain refractory to conservative treatment (Evidence: pg no: 18, L791)
Ligamentous stability either prior to surgery or achieved concurrently (Evidence: pg no: 18, L792)
Normal alignment without varus or valgus deformities (Evidence: pg no: 18, L793)
Mild to moderate articular damage (Outerbridge grade II or less) (Evidence: pg no: 18, L794)

exclusions: Treatment for asymptomatic individuals with partial or complete loss of meniscus (Evidence: pg no: 18, L798)
Use of other meniscal implants incorporating materials such as collagen and polyurethane (Evidence: pg no: 18, L799)

codes.description: Arthroscopy, knee, surgical; meniscal transplantation (includes arthrotomy for meniscal insertion), medial or lateral (Evidence: pg no: 19, L823)
Collagen meniscus implant procedure for filling meniscal defects (eg, CMI, collagen scaffold, Menaflex) (Evidence: pg no: 19, L824)

notes: Goal is reduction in pain, prevention of degenerative changes, and restoration of mechanical properties (Evidence: pg no: 17, L732-L733)
